title-group.article-title: Subconjunctival Emphysema after Orbital Decompression for Graves’ Ophthalmopathy

body.p: A63-year-old man with a 25-year history of worsening proptosis, extraocular motility difficulty, and exposure keratitis of his right eye secondary to Graves’ ophthalmopathy underwent endoscopic sinus surgery with medial and inferior orbital decompression and periorbital stripping. Immediately after surgery, he had no periorbital edema or emphysema. Despite preoperative counseling, he blew his nose on postoperative day 1 and developed acute right-sided proptosis (Figure 1). Examination revealed a cystic appearance of the right lower bulbar conjunctiva extending superiorly with crepitus of the upper and lower eyelids. Vision, light reflexes, and optic nerve function were normal, and extraocular motility was unchanged from preoperative baseline. This case report was exempted from approval by the Columbia University Institutional Review Board.

caption.p: The patient developed severe right-sided proptosis immediately after blowing his nose on postoperative day 1. This close-up image highlights the cystic appearance of the subconjunctival emphysema.

body.p: Subconjuctival emphysema is a recognized yet uncommonly seen complication of sinus surgery. With forceful exhalation by sneezing or nose blowing, air can dissect through a defect in the lamina papyracea or orbital floor into the orbital cavity and surrounding soft tissue.1,2 It is postulated there is either a potential communication or tissue laxity between the subcutaneous and subconjunctival planes, allowing air to spread into this potential space leading to the development of subconjunctival emphysema.3 Resection of the medial and inferior orbital walls, as well as the periosteum, during orbital decompression puts patients at risk of orbital complications.

Because otolaryngologists routinely advise patients against nose blowing and other means of forced exhalation postoperatively, recognizing subconjunctival emphysema is difficult because it is rarely encountered. If patients have no eye pain, decreased visual acuity, or restricted extraocular motility, management is typically conservative as it is often self-limited with spontaneous resolution. Close observation is necessary to avoid developing serious complications, including exposure keratopathy, elevated intraocular pressure, and compressive optic neuropathy.4 Worsening orbital emphysema can result in orbital compartment syndrome and compressive optic neuropathy, requiring lateral canthotomy and cantholysis for acute orbital decompression.4,5
